Alternative: X-GEN (is) Y-NOM. Richard on which is "basic": "the GEN possessive is sometimes called "more Saami", the HAVE-possessive is sometimes said to be associated with "use", so H bijlem atna could be sth like "H has a car (that he can use/he has it HERE". But nothing of this is evident without lots of context. So I'd say HAVE and GEN poss are pretty equal."

This is actually a locative construction with the fairly abstract verb 'to be' (X is around Y). Other predicates are also possible (e.g. 'grow' -- not in the case of 'walls', of course)
